results.title: Princes Street Port Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Lyn McLeavy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A tribute to a suburb, a family and a lady who liked to play the piano and sing the blues. Lyn McLeavey describes growing up in Port Melbourne in the 1950s, blending in the harsh realities of life as the daughter of a traumatised ‘wharfie’, with the simple joy of the sounds of the streets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lyn McLeavy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: A tribute to a suburb, a family and a lady who liked to play the piano and sing the blues. results.title: Coming home
results.creator_credit: Louise Blake, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Despite being born in Canberra, Louise Blake’s family history has very strong ties to Melbourne. Over the years, family trips have drawn Blake ‘south of the border’, where suburbs like Port Melbourne and Brunswick evoke stories from her family history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Louise Blake, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Weeding wars in peaceful places
results.creator_credit: Llywellyn Staiff, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Flora, fauna and bushland is what makes Maroondah and Australia different to anywhere else in the world. The agenda of Llywellyn and her colleagues is to protect what’s left.

results.title: I am safe
results.creator_credit: Joyce Evans, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 2005, the Australian Federal Government introduced new laws to address to potential and perceived threat of terrorism. Dubbed the ‘anti-terrorism’ or sedition law, the outcome of the reforms would enable someone to be detained on suspicion of a terrorist act for up to seven days, with significantly less rights than afforded a suspect of any other criminal act. The laws have given Joyce Evans pause for consideration about whether these measures were really going to make Australia safe in the long run, or leave Australia open to despotic rule in the future.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joyce Evans, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: In 2005, the Australian Federal Government introduced new laws to address to potential and perceived threat of terrorism. Dubbed the ‘anti-terrorism’ or sedition law, the outcome of the reforms would enable someone to be detained on suspicion of a terrorist act for up to seven days, with significantly less rights than afforded a suspect of any other criminal act. The laws have given Joyce Evans pause for consideration about whether these measures were really going to make Australia safe in the long run, or leave Australia open to despotic rule in the future.

Dubbed the ‘anti-terrorism’ or sedition law, the outcome of the reforms would enable someone to be detained on suspicion of a terrorist act for up to seven days, with significantly less rights than afforded a suspect of any other criminal act. The laws have given Joyce Evans pause for consideration about whether these measures were really going to make Australia safe in the long run, or leave Australia open to despotic rule in the future.

results.title: The Port mob
results.creator_credit: Edwin Whiting, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edwin Whiting speaks fondly of his time when he and his mates had the run of Port Melbourne in the 1930s. They spent most of their spare time together, but World War II changed everything.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edwin Whiting, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Like mother...like daughter
results.creator_credit: Christine Lamb, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Christine Lamb is constantly told how much she’s like her mother. It is through looking back on her life and all the things her mother taught her, that Lamb learns how similar they really are.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christine Lamb, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Why plant millions of trees
results.creator_credit: Alfred Zerfas, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alfred Zerfas gives background to and outlines the achievements of Social Education and Development Society (SEDS). This organisation was started in the 1980s in response to the crushing effects of drought in Southern India. With persistance over the decades, the work of SEDS, in collaboration with the communities they support, has brought about economic, social and enviromental change in these communities with lasting benefits.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alfred Zerfas, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Alfred Zerfas gives background to and outlines the achievements of Social Education and Development Society (SEDS). With persistance over the decades, the work of SEDS, in collaboration with the communities they support, has brought about economic, social and enviromental change in these communities with lasting benefits.

results.title: Listen up my cherubs!
results.creator_credit: Karen Milward, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Energetic and intelligent, Karen Milward is constantly engaged with life. Often on the road for her work in the Aboriginal community, her children wonder what it is she actually does. This story is by way of explanation and gives insight into the life of an amazing community worker and consultant.

results.title: About Oskie
results.creator_credit: Norman Terrick, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Norman Terrick believes he would not be the man he is today without his father. He lovingly describes a hard working man, who was good at what he did and always had time for his family. Even though he passed away in 1974, Terrick has created this tribute in memory of an inspiring man.

results.title: My people
results.creator_credit: Linda Kennedy-Baxter, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Linda Kennedy-Baxter talks about her life through the people who have made it special, her family. Her family comes first and have taught her that its the little things that matter.
